analyzed: desāya kataram daṭṭhum icchasi
translated: “The whole or a part? Which do you wish to see?”

original: Ko dukkaroti pucchitvā, eka desāya kampanaṃ;
analyzed: kaḥ pucchitvā eka desāya kampanaṃ
translated: “Which is the more difficult?” asked the king. “To make a part tremble,” was the reply.

analyzed: tam duṭṭhu kāmatam bravī
translated: “That is difficult,” said the king. “I wish to see that.”

analyzed: ratham assam manussam ca pātiñca udaka pūritam
translated: “A chariot, a horse, a man, and a man carrying a vessel full of oil,”

original: Thero yojana sīmāya, antaramhi catuddise.🔽Ṭhapāpetvā tadaḍḍhehi, saha taṃ yojanaṃ mahiṃ;
analyzed: theraḥ yojana sīmāya antaramhi catuddise  ṭhapā petvā saha tam yojanam mahim
translated: “Within a distance of four leagues from the monastery, in the middle of the four directions,”🔽“Having placed them at a distance of one league from the monastery, and having filled the space of one league on every side with men,”

original: Cālesi iddhiyā tatra, nisinnassa ca dassayi.🔽Tenā’maccena bhikkhūnaṃ, maraṇena’ttanopi ca;
analyzed: cālesi iddhiyā tatra nisinnassa ca dassayi  tena amaccena bhikkhūnam ca

analyzed: theram pucchi mahīpati
translated: “By the death of the monks and of himself,” said the king, “was the crime committed or not?”

original: Paṭicca kammaṃ natthīti, kiliṭṭhaṃ cetanaṃ vinā;
analyzed: paṭicca kammam na atthi iti kiliṭṭham cetanam vinā

analyzed: theraḥ rājānam vatvā tittira jātakam
translated: And he instructed the king, relating the Tittiri Jātaka.

analyzed: vasantaḥ tattha sattāham rājuyyāne manorame
translated: Having remained there seven days, in the delightful royal garden,

analyzed: sikkhāpesi mahīpālam sambuddha samayam subham
translated: he instructed the king in the excellent doctrine of the Buddha.

original: Tasmiṃyeva ca sattā he, duve yakkhe mahīpati;
analyzed: ca ca sattā he duve yakkhe mahīpati
translated: And on the seventh day, the king sent two Yakkhas to the earth,

analyzed: pesetvā mahiyam bhikkhū asese sannipātayi
translated: and caused all the monks to assemble.

analyzed: sattame divase gantvā saka ārāmam manoramam
translated: On the seventh day he went to the delightful monastery of the Sakyans,

analyzed: kāresi bhikkhu saṅghassa sannipātam asesataḥ
translated: And caused the entire fraternity of Bhikkhus to assemble.

analyzed: therena saha ekante nisinnaḥ sāṇi antare
translated: Sitting alone with the Thera in a private place,

analyzed: ekekaladdhike bhikkhu pakkositvāna santikaṃ
translated: He summoned the Bhikkhus who had been ordained one by one,

original: Kiṃvādī sugato bhante, iti pucchi mahīpati;
analyzed: kiṃvādī sugataḥ bhante iti pucchi mahīpati
translated: And asked: “What did the Blessed One teach, venerable Sirs?”

analyzed: te sassata ādikam diṭṭhim byākariṃsu yathāsakam
translated: They explained their views, such as the doctrine of eternalism, etc., each according to his opinion.

analyzed: te micchādiṭṭhike sabbe rājā
translated: The king caused all those who held wrong views to be expelled,

analyzed: sabbe saṭṭhi sahassāni āsum uppabbajāpitā
translated: And sixty thousand were expelled.

original: Apucchi dhammike bhikkhū, kiṃvādī sugato iti;
analyzed: apucchi dhammike bhikkhū kiṃvādī sugataḥ iti
translated: He asked the orthodox Bhikkhus: “What did the Blessed One teach?”

original: Vibhajjavādī tāhaṃsu, taṃ theraṃ pucchi bhūpati.
analyzed: vibhajja vādī tam theram pucchi bhūpati
translated: They said: “The Sambuddha teaches the doctrine of the Vibhajjavādins.” The king asked the Thera:

analyzed: vibhajja vādī sambuddhaḥ
translated: “The Sambuddha is a Vibhajjavādī.”

analyzed: hoti bhante iti āha saḥ
translated: “Yes, venerable Sir,” he said.

analyzed: theraḥ tam sutvā
translated: When the Thera heard that,

analyzed: rājā tuṭṭha manaḥ tadā
translated: The king was pleased.

analyzed: saṅghaḥ pisodhitaḥ yasmai
translated: Since the Saṅgha had been purified,

analyzed: tasmai saṅghaḥ uposatham  karotu bhante id ca ivam
translated: Therefore let the Saṅgha, venerable Sirs,

analyzed: vatvā therassa bhūpati
translated: Hold the Uposatha,” thus spoke the king to the Thera.

original: Saṅghassa rakkhaṃ datvāna, nagaraṃ pāvisī subhaṃ;
analyzed: saṅghassa rakkham da tvāna nagaram pāvisī subham
translated: Having given protection to the Saṅgha, he entered the beautiful city.

analyzed: saṅghaḥ samaggaḥ hutvāna uposatham
translated: The Order, having become united, then held the Uposatha.

analyzed: theraḥ bhikkhu saṅghāḥ visārade
translated: The Elder, from the many thousands of the Bhikkhu-Order, who were full of confidence,

analyzed: chaḷabhiññe tepiṭake pabhinna paṭisambhide
translated: who were possessed of the six (supernatural) knowledges, of the three Baskets, and of the (knowledge of the) discrimination (of the 37 requisites of enlightenment),

analyzed: bhikkhu sahassam uccini kātum saddhammam saṅgaham
translated: selected a thousand Bhikkhus to collect the true Dhamma.

analyzed: tehi asoka ārāmamhi akā saddhamma saṅgahaṃ
translated: They collected the true Dhamma in the Asokārāma.

analyzed: mahākassapa thero ca yasa thero ca
translated: The Elder Mahākassapa and the Elder Yasas had done it;

original: Yathā te dhamma saṃgītiṃ, tissattheropi taṃ tathā.🔽Tathāvatthuppakaraṇaṃ, paravādappamaddanaṃ;
analyzed: yathā te dhamma saṃgītim tissa theraḥ api tam tathā  tathā vatthu pakaraṇam paravāda ppamaddanam
translated: just as they had done the rehearsal of the Dhamma, so did the Elder Tissa.

original: Abhāsi tissatthero ca, tasmiṃ saṃgīti maṇḍale.
analyzed: abhāsi tissa theraḥ ca tasmin saṃgīti maṇḍale
translated: The Elder Tissa also recited in the assembly of the rehearsal of the Dhamma the treatise on the Vatthugāthās, which confutes the doctrines of others.

analyzed: evam bhikkhu sahassena rakkhāyasoka rājinaḥ
translated: Thus the king’s protection was extended to the thousand Bhikkhus;

original: Ayaṃ navahi māsehi, dhamma saṃgīti niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ayam navahi māsehi dhamma saṃgīti niṭṭhitā
translated: in nine months the rehearsal of the Dhamma was completed.

original: Rañño sattarase vasse, dvāsattatisamo isi;🔽Mahāpavāraṇāya’so, saṃgīti taṃ samāpayi.🔽Sādhukāraṃ dadantīva, sāsanaṭṭhiti kāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: rañño sattarase vasse dvāsattati samaḥ isi  tam samāpayi  sādhukāram dadanti iva sāsana ṭṭhiti kāraṇam
translated: In the seventeenth year of the king, in the twenty-seventh year of the Seer (Kakusandha),🔽on the Mahāpavāraṇā day, the rehearsal of the Dhamma was concluded.🔽As if giving their approval, the cause of the duration of the Faith,

analyzed: saṃgīti pariyosāne akammittha mahā mahī
translated: the great earth shook at the conclusion of the rehearsal of the Dhamma.

analyzed: hitvā seṭṭham brahma vimānam pi manuññam
translated: Having abandoned the excellent and delightful mansion of Brahmā,

analyzed: konāmaññaḥ sāsana kiccamhi pamajjeti
translated: Who else, named Koṇa, is negligent in the duties of the Dispensation?

analyzed: su jana ppasāda saṃvega tthāya kate mahā vaṃse
translated: In the Great Chronicle composed for the purpose of inspiring faith and a sense of urgency in the good,

analyzed: nāma
translated: The third recitation of the Dhamma, named

analyzed: pañcamo paricchedo

analyzed: chaṭṭha pariccheda
translated: The sixth chapter

analyzed: vijaya āgamanam
translated: The arrival of Vijayā

analyzed: vaṅgesu vaṅga nagare vaṅga rājā ahu pure
translated: In the land of the Vaṅgas, in the city of Vaṅga, there was a king in the past;

analyzed: kāliṅga raññaḥ dhītā asi mahesī tassa rājinaḥ
translated: She was the daughter of the king of Kāliṅga, the chief queen of that king.

original: So rājā deviyā tassā, ekaṃ alabhi dhītaraṃ;
analyzed: saḥ rājā deviyā tassāḥ ekam alabhi dhītaram
translated: That king had one daughter by that queen,

analyzed: tassā saṃvāsam magara ajinā
translated: The signs were declared of her union with the king of Magadha.

analyzed: atīva rūpiniṃ āsi atīva kāmagiddhinī
translated: She was exceedingly beautiful, exceedingly infatuated with love;

analyzed: devena devi yācā api lajjāyāḥ asi jagucchitā
translated: By the god, by the queen, by shame, she was disgusted.

analyzed: ekākinī sā nikkhamma serī cāra sukhatthinī
translated: Alone she went forth, delighting in the pleasure of wandering about;

analyzed: satthena saha aññātā agāḥ magadhagāminā
translated: Unknown with a sword, she went on the road to Magadha.

analyzed: lāḷaraṭṭhe aṭaviyā sīhaḥ
translated: In the forest of the Lāḷa country, a lion attacked the sword;

analyzed: aññattha sesā dhāviṃsu
translated: The rest ran away elsewhere, frightened by the lion's roar.

original: Gaṇhitvā gocaraṃ sīho, gacchaṃ disvā tamā’rato;
analyzed: gaṇhitvā gocaram sīhaḥ gaccham disvā
translated: The lion, having seized his prey, went away, and the she-jackal, seeing him, followed him.

analyzed: rattaḥ laṅgulam pattakaṇṇakaḥ
translated: The lion, being enamoured, went to the top of a precipice, and the she-jackal, following him, fell over the precipice.

original: Sā taṃ disvā saritvāna, nemittavacanaṃ sutaṃ;🔽Abhītā tassa aṅgāni, rañjayanti parāmasi.🔽Tassā phassenā’ti ratto, piṭṭhiṃ āropiyā’sutaṃ;
analyzed: sā tam disvā saritvāna nemitta vacanam sutam  abhītā tassa aṅgāni rañjayanti parāmasi  tassā phassena ati rattaḥ piṭṭhim āropiya a sutam
translated: She, seeing him, remembered the words of the seer, and, being fearless, stroked his limbs.

original: Sīho sakaṃ guhaṃ netvā, tāya saṃvāsamācari.
analyzed: sīhaḥ sakam guham netvā tāya saṃvāsam ācari
translated: The lion, being enamoured of her touch, took her on his back, and went to his own cave.

analyzed: tena saṃvāsam anvāya kālena yamake duve
translated: Having lived together with her, in time she gave birth to twins,

original: Puttañca dhītarañcāti, rājadhītā janesi sā.🔽Puttassa hatthapādā’suṃ, sīhākārā tato akā;
analyzed: puttam ca dhītaram ca ati rāja dhītā janesi sā  puttassa hattha pāda asum sīha ākārā
translated: a son and a daughter. The princess gave birth to them.🔽The hands and feet of the son were like those of a lion, therefore he was called Sīhabāhu (Lion-armed).

analyzed: nāmena sīhabāhum tam dhītaram sīha sīvalim
translated: The daughter was called Sīhasīvalī (Lion-maned).

original: Putto soḷasavasso so, mātaraṃ pucchi saṃsayaṃ;
analyzed: putto soḷasa vassaḥ saḥ mātaram pucchi saṃsayam
translated: When the son was sixteen years old, he asked his mother a question:

original: Tuvaṃ pitā ca no amma, kasmā visadisā iti.
analyzed: tuvam pitā ca naḥ amma kasmai visadisau iti
translated: “Mother, you and our father are unlike each other.”

analyzed: sā sabbam abravī tassa kiṃnayāma ati sā ubravi
translated: She told him everything. He said: “What did you do?”

analyzed: guham te pāsāṇena ati sā bravi
translated: “I struck your father with a stone in the cave.”

analyzed: mahā guhāya thakanam khandhena ādāya saḥ
translated: He took a rock and struck the great cave,

analyzed: eka ahena iva paññāsa yojanāni gata āgatam
translated: and in one day he had gone and returned fifty leagues.

original: Gocarāya gahe sīhe, dakkhiṇasmiñhi mātaraṃ;🔽Vāme kaṇiṭṭhiṃ katvāna, tayo sīghaṃ apakkamī.
analyzed: gocarāya gahe sīhe dakkhiṇasmin hi mātaram  vāme kaṇiṭṭhim katvāna tayaḥ sīgham apakkamī
translated: The lion took his mother on his right side,🔽and his sister on his left, and quickly went away.

analyzed: nivāsetvāna sākham te paccantam gāmam āgamum
translated: Having dressed them, they went to a village in the border country,

original: Tatthāsi rājidhītāya, mātulassa suto tadā.🔽Senāpati vaṅgarañño, ṭhito paccanta gāmako;
analyzed: tattha asi rājidhītāya mātulassa sutaḥ tadā  senāpati vaṅgaraññaḥ ṭhito paccanta gāmako
translated: and there was the daughter of the King, the son of her uncle.🔽The general of the King of Vaṅga, who was stationed in the border village,

analyzed: kammantam saṃvidhāyakam
translated: while sitting at the foot of a tree, was arranging his affairs.

original: Disvā te pucchite’vocuṃ, aṭavī vāsino mayaṃ;
analyzed: disvā te aṭavī vāsinaḥ mayam
translated: Seeing them he asked, “Where have you come from?” They said, “We are forest-dwellers,”

original: Iti so dāpayī tesaṃ, vatthāni dhajinī pati.
analyzed: iti saḥ tesam vatthāni dhajinī pati
translated: and he gave them clothes, and the general’s wife.

analyzed: uḷārāni bhattam paṇṇesu dāpayi
translated: They were very generous, and gave them food on leaves,

analyzed: tesam puññena tāni ca
translated: and they had golden bowls, and by their merit they were filled.

original: Tena so vimhito pucchi, ke tumheti camūpati;
analyzed: tena saḥ vimhitaḥ pucchi ke tumhā iti camūpati
translated: The general asked them, “Who are you?”

analyzed: tassa sā jāti gottāni rāja dhītā
translated: The King’s daughter told him her family and lineage.

original: Pitucchā dhītaraṃ taṃ so, ādāya dhajinī pati;
analyzed: pitucchā dhītaram tam sā u ādāya dhajinī pati
translated: The general took the daughter,

analyzed: gantvāna vaṅga nagaram saṃvāsam tāya
translated: and having gone to the city of Vaṅga, he made an agreement with her.

original: Sīho sīghaṃ guhaṃ gantvā, te adisvā tayo jane;
analyzed: sīhaḥ u sīgham guham gantvā te adisvā tayaḥ jane
translated: The lion quickly went to the cave, and not seeing the three men,

original: Aṭṭito puttasokena, na ca khādi na cā’pivi.
analyzed: aṭṭitaḥ putta sokena na ca khādi na ca apivi
translated: was afflicted with grief for his sons, and neither ate nor drank.

analyzed: dārake te gavesantaḥ agā paccanta gāmake
translated: Searching for the children, he went to the village on the frontier,

original: Ubbāsīyati so so’va, yaṃyaṃ gāmamupeti so.
analyzed: ubbāsīyati saḥ saḥ uva yaṃ yam gāmam upeti saḥ
translated: and was disappointed, wherever he went, in that village or another.

analyzed: paccanta vāsinaḥ gantvā raññaḥ tam paṭivedayum
translated: The inhabitants of the frontier went and informed the king,

original: Sīho piḷeti te raṭṭhaṃ, taṃ deva paṭisedhaya.
analyzed: sīhaḥ piḷeti te raṭṭham tam deva paṭisedhaya
translated: “The lion is afflicting the country, O King, restrain him.”

analyzed: alakam nisedhakam tassa hatthi khandha gatam pure
translated: Alakandaka, the restrainer, mounted on the back of an elephant,

analyzed: ādetu sīha dāyī iti sahassam saḥ pacārayi
translated: “Let him be brought,” and he ordered a thousand (men) to be sent.

analyzed: tathā iva dve sahassāni narissaro
translated: In the same way two and three thousand, the lord of men,

original: Dvīsu vāresu vāresi, mātā sīhabhujaṃ hitaṃ.🔽Aggahi tatiye vāre, sīhabāhu apucchiya;
analyzed: dvīsu vāresu mātā sīha bhujam hitam  aggahi tatiye vāre sīha bāhu a pucchiya
translated: in two instances restrained the mother, who was dear to the arm of the lion.🔽In the third instance he seized (her), and asked the mother,

original: Mātaraṃ tisahassaṃ taṃ, ghātetuṃ pitaraṃ sakaṃ.
analyzed: mātaram ti sahassam tam ghātetum pitaram sakam
translated: “Kill the three thousand, and your own father.”

original: Rañño kumāraṃ dassesuṃ, taṃ rājā idha mabravi;
analyzed: raññaḥ kumāram dassesum tam rājā idha mabravi
translated: They showed the prince to the king, and the king said to him here,

original: Gahito yadi sīho te, dammi raṭṭhaṃ tadeva te.
analyzed: gahitaḥ yadi sīhaḥ te dammi raṭṭham tat eva te
translated: “If you seize the lion, I will give you the kingdom.”

original: So taṃ gantvā guhādvāraṃ, sīhaṃ disvāva ārakā;
analyzed: sā u tam gantvā guhā dvāram sīham ārakā
translated: He went to the entrance of the cave, and seeing the lion from a distance,

original: Entaṃ puttasinehena, vijjhituṃ taṃ saraṃ khipi.
analyzed: ā intam putta sinehena vijjhitum tam saram khipi
translated: and hurled it at the lake to pierce it.

analyzed: saraḥ metta cittena thassa tu
translated: The arrow, striking the Nāla tree, fell down with a friendly mind;

analyzed: kumāra pāda mūlā iva nivattaḥ bhūmiyam
translated: and returned to the foot of the prince and fell down on the ground.

analyzed: tathā asi yāva tatiyam tatas kujjhimi gāmipo
translated: So it was up to the third time, then the prince became angry and went to the deer;

original: Tato khitto sarotassa, kāyaṃ nibbijja nikkhami.
analyzed: tatas khittaḥ sarotassa kāyam nibbijja nikkhami
translated: then the arrow, shot by the prince, having pierced the body of the deer, came out.

analyzed: sa kesaram sīha sīsam ādāya sa puram agāḥ
translated: Taking the golden lion’s head, he went to the city;

analyzed: matassa vaṅga rājassa sattāhāni tadā ahu
translated: for seven days there was (mourning) for the dead king Vaṅga.

original: Rañño aputtakattā ca, patītā cassa kammunā;
analyzed: raññaḥ a puttaka ttā ca patītā ca ssa kammunā
translated: Because the king had no son, and because he had fallen by his own deed,

original: Sutvā ca rañño nattuttaṃ, sañjānitvā ca mātaraṃ.
analyzed: sutvā ca raññaḥ nattuttam sañjānitvā ca mātaram
translated: and having heard the king’s lamentation, and having recognised his mother,

analyzed: amaccā sannipatitā akhilā eka mānasā
translated: the ministers assembled, all of one mind;

analyzed: sīhabāhu kumārassa rājā hohi iti abravuṃ
translated: and they said: “Let Prince Sīhabāhu be king.”

original: So rajjaṃ sampaṭicchitvā, datvā mātu patissa taṃ;
analyzed: saḥ rajjam sampaṭicchitvā da tvā mātu patissa tam
translated: He accepted the kingdom, and gave his mother the royal estate,

analyzed: sīha sīvalim ādāya jāta bhūmim gataḥ sayam
translated: and taking the lion’s head, he went to his own birthplace.

original: Nagaraṃ tattha māpesi, ahu sīhapuranti taṃ;
analyzed: nagaram tattha mā āpesi ahu sīhapuram ti tam
translated: He built a city there, and it was called Sīhapura;

analyzed: araññe yojana sate gāme ca api
translated: and in the forest a hundred leagues around, and in the villages, he settled people.

analyzed: lāḷaraṭṭhe pure tasmim sīhabāhu narādhipo
translated: In that city in the Lāḷa country, the king Sīhabāhu,

analyzed: rajjam kāresi katvāna mahā isim sīha sīvalim
translated: and after reigning, he made the queen, Sīhasīvali, his chief queen.

original: Mahesī soḷasakkhattuṃ, yamake ca duve duve;
analyzed: mahesī soḷasakkhattum yamake ca duve duve
translated: That chief queen sixteen times gave birth to twins,

original: Putte janayi kālesā, vijayo nāma jeṭṭhako.
analyzed: putte janayi kālesā vijayaḥ nāma jeṭṭhako
translated: two sons each time, and at the end of time, a son named Vijaya was born, the eldest.

original: Sumitto nāma dutiyo, sabbe dvattiṃsa puttakā;
analyzed: sumittaḥ nāma dutiyaḥ sabbe dvattiṃsa puttakā
translated: The second was named Sumitta, and all the thirty-two sons,

analyzed: kālena vijayam rājā secayi
translated: in time, the king anointed Vijaya as heir to the throne.

analyzed: vijayaḥ visamācāraḥ ca
translated: Vijaya was of irregular conduct, and his retinue also,

analyzed: sāhasāni anekāni dussahāni kariṃsute
translated: and they committed many violent and difficult (acts).

analyzed: kuddhaḥ mahā janaḥ raññaḥ tam attham paṭivedayi
translated: The angry people informed the king of that matter,
